title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and it pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The Social Security Act is amended to ensure the completeness, timeliness, and accuracy of transmitting information regarding deceased individuals. The Social Security Act is amended to allow the use of information on deceased individuals by federal and state agencies for benefit programs, with safeguards in place to protect the information from unauthorized use or disclosure. The Commissioner of Social Security can enter into arrangements with federal or agency Inspector Generals for reimbursement of costs related to sharing information on deceased individuals, as long as it does not conflict with their duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can provide information on deceased individuals for federal agencies to use in the Do Not Pay working system, as long as certain requirements are met. The working system can compare death information provided by the Commissioner with personally identifiable information and share it with authorized Federal or State agencies. This is done to ensure proper payments under Federal programs, tax administration, or debt collection. The Commissioner of Social Security can share deceased individuals' information with Federal or State agencies for various purposes, including tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention or investigation. Similar arrangements can be made with States for the same purposes or for use in State-funded programs. The Commissioner of Social Security can use deceased individuals' information for State-funded programs or pension plans if certain requirements are met. This information can be shared with Federal or State agencies for tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention purposes. The Commissioner of Social Security can implement safeguards to protect information from unauthorized use or disclosure for statistical and research purposes by Federal and State agencies. This includes sharing information with agencies for tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention. The amendments made to section 205(r) of the Social Security Act will be repealed after 5 years. Additionally, section 6103(d)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be amended. The amendments to the Social Security Act involve replacing the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the Commissioner of Social Security in certain subparagraphs. Additionally, a report to Congress on alternative sources of death data is required. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, including State agencies, focusing on accuracy, completeness, and accessibility. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review the accessibility, cost, security, reliability, and comparison of potential alternate sources of death data for Federal agencies in a report to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of the Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress with a recommendation on extending agency access to death data provided by the Commissioner of Social Security. SEC. 7 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 amends the act to improve the use of death data by government agencies. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on maintaining databases of beneficiary information within 6 months of the enactment of the section. The Office of Management and Budget will provide access to death databases for agencies and components within 6 months of enactment. Additionally, a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations will be implemented within 1 year. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to help states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations provide electronic death records to the Federal Government, including recommendations for any necessary statutory changes or financial assistance. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to improve data matching for payments to deceased individuals, in consultation with relevant federal agencies, states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. The plan may include recommendations for funding to carry it out. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a plan to Congress to enhance data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. Additionally, annual reports on the implementation of this plan will be provided for five years. The Director will submit a plan to Congress for data matching on deceased individuals receiving federal benefits. The first report will include the Director's recommendations. Definitions for 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are provided in this section. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING THE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY THE SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including data on individuals not receiving benefits under titles II or XVI of the Social Security Act. The plan must include a procedure for identifying extremely elderly individuals. The plan must include a procedure for identifying extremely elderly individuals who are still alive according to Social Security Administration records and verifying the accuracy of this information. Improved policies and procedures are needed for identifying and correcting erroneous records, including those for individuals listed as dead who are actually alive, those listed as alive who are actually dead, and allowing individuals or survivors of deceased individuals. The plan includes procedures to identify errors in Social Security records, implement improved policies for correcting erroneous data, use statistical analysis to estimate the number of errors, and make recommendations for legislation. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement the plan within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
